title: Research Science Initiative (RSI) at MIT
details: A 6-week intensive summer research program for high school students. The best and most prestigious HS Research EC available. Its completely free of cost and even travel stipends are available for students. So, you get to research at MIT for 6 weeks for completely FREE OF COST. Participants engage in hands-on research under the guidance of MIT faculty and researchers, focusing on topics such as chemistry, physics, computer science, and engineering. Develop advanced research skills, present findings in reports and posters, and gain mentorship in scientific methodology and experimental design.
eligibility: RSI applicants are students with outstanding academic achievements who are entering their final year of high school. Typically, this means they apply during the middle of their junior year (grade 11). High school seniors are not eligible to apply. Each participating country has its own selection procedure and selection schedule. Please contact RSI to determine if your country participates.
tips: Emphasize your goals in STEM through your application essays. Strong standardized test scores (PSAT, SAT, ACT, AP) are recommended, but lower scores can be balanced by excellent grades, strong recommendations, and evidence of scientific or mathematical potential.
whatIsLookedFor: RSI seeks students with exceptional potential in STEM who demonstrate curiosity, self-motivation, and a passion for research. Applicants typically show strong academic achievement in math and science and take rigorous STEM courses. While prior research experience is helpful, it is not required—students can demonstrate interest through independent projects, science fairs, personal experiments, online courses, or challenging problems tackled outside school. Strong standardized test scores are recommended (PSAT Math ≥740, PSAT Evidence-Based Reading & Writing ≥700, SAT Math ≥750, ACT Math ≥33, ACT English/Verbal ≥34), but slightly lower scores can be offset by outstanding essays, recommendations, or demonstrated STEM potential. Engagement in STEM extracurriculars, leadership, and community contributions strengthens an application. Essays should clearly show curiosity, initiative, problem-solving ability, and self-directed learning. Students in areas with limited STEM opportunities are encouraged to highlight their resourcefulness and determination.

title: Summer Science Program (SSP)
details: A 5-week intensive residential research program on the campus of a renowned research university for rising high school seniors. Participants engage in hands-on research in topics such as Astrophysics, Biochemistry, Bacterial Genomics, Cell Biology and Synthetic Chemistry. Students work in teams, develop advanced research skills, and present their findings through reports and posters. The program emphasizes curiosity, problem-solving, and collaboration under the guidance of expert mentors.
eligibility: Open to students currently in Class 11 (rising seniors) in India (CBSE, ISC, or equivalent). Applicants must have completed or be completing relevant STEM coursework by June for credit and a grade. For CBSE/ISC students, this includes courses in Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, and Biology relevant to the chosen research track. Students must be between 15 and 18 years old during the program. Current Class 9, 10, or 12 students are not eligible. Advanced courses (AP/A-level) are not required, but self-study or incomplete coursework does not qualify.
tips: Highlight STEM excellence: Showcase your achievements in Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics, or Biology. Even if you study in a Tier 2 or Tier 3 city, emphasize initiative through independent projects, science fairs, or problem-solving outside school.

Essays matter: Clearly convey your curiosity, problem-solving skills, and passion for research. Explain why SSP aligns with your goals and how you can contribute to a collaborative research environment.
Recommendations: Obtain strong letters from teachers who can attest to your academic ability and scientific curiosity.

Standardized tests: Indian students do not need AP or SAT scores for admission. The only exception is international applicants needing to demonstrate English proficiency, in which case submitting a strong SAT/English score is recommended.

Financial aid: Need is not a factor in admission. SSP provides financial aid covering 100% of demonstrated need, including airfare and other travel expenses. There is no application fee, ensuring accessibility for students from all regions.

Use your context: Emphasize resourcefulness, self-directed learning, and initiative, especially if your school lacks advanced STEM resources. SSP values curiosity and potential as much as formal achievements.
whatIsLookedFor: Students demonstrating academic excellence, curiosity, initiative, problem-solving skills, and the ability to collaborate effectively in teams. Prior research experience is helpful but not required.

title: PROMYS India Math Program
details: PROMYS India is a 6-week residential summer program in mathematics held at the Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bengaluru. It offers an immersive experience in mathematical exploration for talented high school students from Standards IX to XII. Participants engage in intensive mathematical problem-solving, fostering a deep understanding of mathematical concepts and developing collaborative skills.
eligibility: Open to students currently in Standards IX to XII (or +1, +2, or PUC) in India. Applicants must have completed or be completing Standard IX before the start of the program. Students finishing their final year of higher secondary school or taking a gap year are eligible, provided they have not yet begun university studies. All types of schools in India—government, government-aided, private, independent, sixth form colleges, or home schools—are eligible. Applicants must be at least 15 years old and younger than 19 at the start of the program. Lectures and activities are in English, so applicants should have sufficient English proficiency to participate fully. Students already attending university are not eligible.
tips: Demonstrate a strong passion for mathematics and problem-solving.

All students at PROMYS India 2025 will be awarded full scholarships which covered all tuition, housing and meals for the six weeks of the programme. In addition, applicants may apply for need-based funding for travel and laundry expenses.
Showcase any independent mathematical projects or achievements.
Obtain letters of recommendation from teachers who can attest to your mathematical abilities and enthusiasm.
Prepare for a rigorous program that emphasizes deep mathematical thinking and collaboration.
whatIsLookedFor: Applicants who exhibit a deep interest in mathematics, strong problem-solving skills, and the ability to collaborate effectively in teams. PROMYS India values not only correct solutions but also creative approaches, novel methods, and original reasoning in tackling the Application Problem Set. Prior experience in mathematical competitions or independent mathematical study is advantageous but not required. The program looks for students who demonstrate curiosity, persistence, and innovative thinking in exploring mathematical problems.

title: PROMYS International Math Program at BU
details: PROMYS is a 6-week intensive summer program in mathematics for highly motivated high school students from the U.S. and around the world at Boston University with approximately 80 high school students and 25 undergraduate counselors. Participants engage in deep mathematical exploration, solving challenging problems in number theory and related areas. The program emphasizes creativity, perseverance, and collaborative problem-solving under the mentorship of faculty and experienced counselors.
eligibility: Open to students in India who have completed Standard IX (or equivalent) and are at least 14 years old. Applicants must not yet be enrolled as full-time college or university students.
tips: Demonstrate deep interest in mathematics and problem-solving through the solutions submission to a challenging problem set
Highlight participation in math competitions, independent study, or related projects.
Obtain strong letters of recommendation from teachers familiar with your mathematical abilities.
Prepare for rigorous exploration of challenging problems, focusing on creative and original approaches, not just solutions, through essays.

Financial aid for international students is considered on a case-by-case basis. If you are an international student who requires financial aid to attend PROMYS, we encourage you to apply and submit a financial aid form by the application deadline.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with strong mathematical curiosity, problem-solving skills, and the ability to work collaboratively. PROMYS emphasizes creative approaches, original reasoning, and persistence in exploring mathematical problems rather than just arriving at solutions. Prior competition experience is helpful but not required.

title: Stanford University Mathematics Camp (SUMaC)
details: SUMaC is an intensive 3–4 week summer program for highly motivated high school students from around the world, offered both online and residential at Stanford University. Participants engage in advanced mathematical exploration through lectures, problem sets, and guided research in topics such as abstract algebra, number theory, and topology. The program emphasizes creativity, perseverance, and collaborative problem-solving, providing students with a college-level experience and exposure to current mathematical research.
eligibility: Open to students in India who are currently in Standards X–XI (or equivalent) at the time of application. Applicants must have completed Standard IX (or equivalent) before the program starts and must not yet be enrolled as full-time college students. Students who will be 18 years or older during the program are not eligible for the residential program but may apply for the online option. Minimum age requirement is 14 years.
tips: Showcase your interest and curiosity in advanced mathematics through prior coursework, problem-solving, or math competitions.
Financial aid is granted based upon demonstrated financial need. Aid is open to all applicants and applying for financial aid does not have an effect on your admissions decision.
Highlight independent projects or mathematical exploration outside school.
Obtain strong recommendation letters from teachers who can attest to your mathematical ability and collaborative skills.
Prepare for rigorous problem sets and demonstrate creativity in your approaches rather than just solutions.
For international students, apply for financial aid if needed to cover program tuition and related costs.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with a strong interest in mathematics, problem-solving ability, and collaborative skills. SUMaC values creative approaches, original reasoning, and persistence in tackling challenging problems, not just arriving at correct answers. Prior math competition experience is helpful but not required.

title: ISRO Young Scientist Programme (YUVIKA)
details: YUVIKA is a two-week residential program by ISRO designed to introduce younger students to Space Technology, Space Science, and Space Applications. Participants engage in lectures, hands-on activities, project work, and educational visits. The program is conducted at seven ISRO centres across India and emphasizes curiosity, problem-solving, teamwork, and an understanding of India's space missions and technologies.
eligibility: Open to students in India who have completed Standard VIII and are currently studying in Standard IX (or equivalent). Applicants must not yet be enrolled as full-time college or university students. Minimum age requirement is 14 years.
tips: Demonstrate a strong interest in space science and technology through academic projects or personal exploration.
Participate in science-related extracurricular activities and highlight any relevant achievements.
Obtain recommendation letters from teachers who can attest to your scientific aptitude and curiosity.
Be prepared for hands-on activities, project evaluations, and quizzes during the program.
Show enthusiasm and teamwork, as collaborative participation is highly valued.
whatIsLookedFor: YUVIKA seeks students with strong academic performance, curiosity, and active engagement in science and extracurricular activities. Selection is based on a combination of academic marks (Class 8 or equivalent), performance in an online quiz, participation in science fairs, Olympiads, or equivalent competitions, achievements in sports, membership in Scouts, Guides, NCC, or NSS, and enrollment in rural or village schools. The program values well-rounded students who demonstrate interest, initiative, and collaborative potential in STEM and related activities.

title: World Science Scholars (WSS) Program
details: World Science Scholars (WSS) is a highly selective, free one-year program for extraordinarily gifted high school students worldwide. Participants take interactive courses led by world-renowned scientists in fields such as astrophysics, neuroscience, and computational thinking. The program includes asynchronous coursework, live sessions, and collaborative projects, giving students the opportunity to engage deeply with advanced scientific topics. Participants join a global community of 350+ students, working together on course projects under the mentorship of Nobel laureates and visionary researchers.
eligibility: Open to students in India currently in Standards IX–XII (or equivalent) with exceptional mathematical talent. Applicants must be enrolled in high school (or an accelerated middle school program) and able to complete the one-year program before starting university. Students should demonstrate strong mathematical ability, motivation to learn beyond the school curriculum, and the capacity to discuss complex scientific and mathematical ideas in English. Applicants must have access to a computer with reliable internet and be able to commit an average of two hours per week throughout the academic year.
tips: Highlight your achievements in science and mathematics, including independent projects, competitions, or research.
Demonstrate curiosity and initiative in exploring advanced scientific topics.
Obtain strong recommendation letters from teachers who can attest to your scientific ability and problem-solving skills.
Engage thoughtfully with application materials, showing interest in the specific research topics and faculty mentorship.
Financial need is not a barrier, as the program is fully free for admitted students.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with exceptional scientific curiosity, strong problem-solving ability, and the capacity to collaborate in an international academic setting. Creativity, persistence, and original thinking in exploring scientific problems are highly valued.

title: Anveshana Research Program by Prayoga
details: Anveshana is a 4–5 month research program designed for high school students in India, focused on hands-on scientific exploration under the mentorship of experienced researchers. Participants work on innovative projects across five thematic areas: Green Chemistry, Advanced and Functional Materials, Earth Sciences, Wellness, and Food & Agriculture. The program provides access to state-of-the-art research facilities, real-world research experience, and opportunities to publish in international peer-reviewed journals. Students develop critical thinking, problem-solving skills, and collaboration through guided research and project work.
eligibility: Open to students in India currently in Standards VIII–XII (or equivalent). Applicants should have a strong interest in science and be willing to commit to a 4–5 month research project. Prior experience in science competitions or independent research is beneficial but not required.
tips: Demonstrate curiosity and passion for scientific research through prior projects, experiments, or science fairs.
Highlight teamwork, problem-solving skills, and perseverance in learning.
Obtain recommendation letters from teachers who can attest to your scientific aptitude and initiative.
Show interest in one of the five thematic research areas offered by Anveshana.
Be prepared to engage deeply in research, explore unknown outcomes, and contribute creatively to the project.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with strong scientific curiosity, problem-solving abilities, initiative, and collaborative skills. Anveshana values creativity, critical thinking, and persistence in conducting original research.

title: CERN-Solvay Student Research Camp
details: The CERN-Solvay student camps are week-long residential programs for high school students aged 16 and above. Students experience life at CERN, the world’s largest particle physics laboratory, conducting hands-on experiments, visiting research facilities, attending lectures with scientists, exploring scientific careers, and collaborating with peers from around the world.
eligibility: High school students aged 16 or older, enrolled in high school, with a digital certificate from the CERN-Solvay online physics course, and proficient in English.
tips: Complete the CERN-Solvay online physics course thoroughly before applying.
Demonstrate curiosity, motivation, and a clear interest in physics.
Prepare a strong application including a motivation video, reference letter, and recent grade report.
whatIsLookedFor: Passion for science, curiosity, motivation, teamwork, and readiness for hands-on research experiences.

title: Summer Linguistic Institute for Youth Scholars (SLIYS)
details: Organized by the Ohio State University Department of Linguistics, SLIYS introduces high school students to linguistics, the scientific study of human language. Participants engage in daily live sessions covering phonetics, morphology, syntax, and language documentation. The program includes interactive fieldwork and experimental components, allowing scholars to analyze language like professional linguists.
eligibility: High school students interested in linguistics and language study.
tips: Have a curiosity about languages and how they work.
Be prepared to engage actively in live sessions and exercises.
Review basic concepts in phonetics, morphology, and syntax if possible before attending.
whatIsLookedFor: Curiosity about languages, analytical thinking, and willingness to participate in hands-on linguistics exercises.

title: Yale Young Global Scholars (YYGS)
details: YYGS is a two-week intensive residential academic program at Yale University for highly motivated high school students from around the world. Participants immerse themselves in interdisciplinary learning, taking part in one of several thematic sessions such as Innovations in Science & Technology, Politics, Law & Economics, or Solving Global Challenges. The program emphasizes intellectual curiosity, collaborative problem-solving, and leadership skills, with lectures, seminars, and group projects led by Yale faculty and expert mentors.
eligibility: Open to students in India currently in Standards X–XI (or equivalent) at the time of application. Applicants must have strong academic performance and demonstrate leadership potential. Students must be able to travel to the USA and obtain any required visa. The program is residential and students should be prepared for a fully immersive on-campus experience.
tips: Highlight academic achievements and intellectual curiosity in your chosen thematic area.
Demonstrate leadership, initiative, and teamwork experience, including extracurricular activities or projects.
Obtain strong recommendation letters from teachers familiar with your academic and leadership abilities.
Explain clearly in essays why you are interested in the session and how it aligns with your goals.
Financial aid is available based on need; submit all required documentation on time.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with strong academic abilities, curiosity, leadership potential, and collaborative skills. YYGS values initiative, creativity, and the ability to engage deeply with interdisciplinary topics.

title: Harvard-MIT Mathematics Tournament (HMMT)
details: HMMT is a prestigious high school mathematics competition hosted by Harvard University and MIT. Students compete individually or in teams in challenging problem-solving rounds, including algebra, geometry, combinatorics, and calculus. The tournament includes both November and February events, with opportunities for team collaboration, education sessions, and social engagement.
eligibility: High school students under 21, enrolled in full-time primary or secondary education, and not belonging to more than one organization in a given season. Teams must meet geographic or school affiliation requirements.
tips: Practice previous HMMT problem sets to understand difficulty and format.
Develop team coordination and problem-solving strategies for timed rounds.
Participate in math clubs or competitions to strengthen analytical skills.
whatIsLookedFor: Strong mathematical problem-solving skills, teamwork, creativity, accuracy under timed conditions, and familiarity with advanced topics.

title: Microsoft Imagine Cup
details: The Microsoft Imagine Cup is a global student technology competition that encourages young innovators to create applications, games, and solutions addressing real-world problems using Microsoft technologies. Participants work in teams to develop prototypes, receive mentorship, and compete for prizes and recognition on a global stage.
eligibility: Open to students globally, typically aged 16+, enrolled in high school or university. Teams can be international.
tips: Focus on solving a real-world problem with a clear technological solution.
Build a prototype demonstrating functionality and user experience.
Prepare a compelling presentation or pitch to showcase your idea.
whatIsLookedFor: Innovation, creativity, technical skill, teamwork, problem-solving, and potential societal impact.

title: India National Science Exhibition & Fair (INSEF)
details: INSEF is a national-level science exhibition and competition for school and college students across India. Participants present innovative science and technology projects, prototypes, and experiments. The event aims to promote scientific temper, creativity, and research skills among students, with opportunities for mentorship, awards, and recognition at the national level.
eligibility: Students in grades 6–12 from schools across India. Individual and team projects accepted.
tips: Develop a clear, well-documented project with innovative scientific ideas.
Prepare a strong presentation and prototype to demonstrate your concept.
Engage with mentors and seek feedback during project development.
whatIsLookedFor: Innovation, creativity, scientific reasoning, clarity in presentation, and practical demonstration of concepts.

title: √mathroots at MIT
details: √mathroots is a 14-day mathematical talent accelerator summer program hosted by MIT PRIMES for high-potential high school students. The program focuses on creative mathematics, problem solving, and fostering resilience, resourcefulness, and initiative in overcoming learning challenges. Students engage in rigorous math sessions and collaborative problem-solving activities.
eligibility: High-potential high school students interested in exploring creative mathematics and problem solving, encouraged to apply even if they have faced barriers to learning.
tips: Demonstrate creativity and problem-solving skills in your application.
Highlight resilience, resourcefulness, and initiative in overcoming learning challenges.
Engage actively with peers during collaborative problem-solving sessions.
whatIsLookedFor: Mathematical talent, creativity, initiative, resilience, and collaborative problem-solving ability.

title: Telluride Association Summer Seminar (TASS)
details: TASS is a free, intensive, residential summer program for high school sophomores and juniors, designed to foster critical thinking, democratic community, and intellectual growth. Participants attend college-level seminars in humanities and social sciences, engage in small-group discussions, lectures, and workshops, and write essays under the guidance of experienced faculty. The program also emphasizes community living, collaborative decision-making, transformative justice, and public speaking skills. Students gain a holistic educational experience combining academic rigor with personal and social development.
eligibility: Open to students in India currently in Standards X–XI (or equivalent) at the time of application. Applicants must be at least 15 years old by the start of the program and no older than 17 by the end of the program. Both US and international students are welcome. Participants must be intellectually curious, self-motivated, and able to thrive in a residential community setting.
tips: Demonstrate intellectual curiosity and engagement with social, historical, and cultural topics.
Show leadership, teamwork, and community-mindedness in school or extracurricular activities.
Obtain strong recommendation letters from teachers familiar with your academic and personal abilities.
Prepare thoughtful responses in essays and application materials reflecting your interests and goals.
Be ready to fully participate in residential community life and collaborative decision-making.
whatIsLookedFor: Students who are intellectually curious, self-motivated, and community-minded. TASS values critical thinking, collaborative skills, leadership potential, and the ability to engage deeply with complex social and humanities topics. A willingness to actively participate in a residential community is essential.

title: Algoverse AI Research Program
details: The Algoverse AI Research Program is a hands-on, intensive summer program for high school students interested in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data science. Participants work on real-world AI projects under the mentorship of experts, exploring areas such as computer vision, natural language processing, reinforcement learning, and ethical AI. The program emphasizes practical skills, research experience, collaborative problem-solving, and the development of AI applications.
eligibility: Open to students in India currently in Standards IX–XII (or equivalent) and UG students. Applicants must have a strong interest in AI and computer science, be motivated to work on research projects, and have basic programming knowledge in Python or another programming language. No prior research experience is required.
tips: They offer scholarships to exceptional applicants who cannot afford the program fee.
Showcase independent projects, competitions, or hackathons related to AI or STEM.
Obtain recommendation letters from teachers or mentors who can attest to your technical ability and curiosity.
Be prepared to demonstrate problem-solving skills and creativity in AI project submissions.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with strong curiosity in AI and machine learning, problem-solving ability, and collaborative skills. Algoverse values initiative, creativity, and persistence in exploring AI concepts and developing innovative solutions.

title: Lumiere Scholars Essay Award
details: The Lumiere Scholars Essay Award is a world-class essay competition for ambitious high school students, open globally. Participants explore issues that matter to them, cross disciplinary boundaries, test assumptions, and defend arguments with rigorous evidence. Essays are reviewed by an international panel of distinguished professors and researchers. Winners receive cash prizes and scholarships to Lumiere's Individual Research Program, fostering critical thinking, effective communication, and research skills.
eligibility: Open to high school students in India (Standards IX–XII or equivalent). Participants should have strong writing, critical thinking, and research skills. No prior experience is required, but students should be motivated to explore complex topics and present well-supported arguments.
tips: Choose a prompt that resonates with your interests and allows for critical exploration.
Demonstrate clarity of thought, originality, and depth of analysis in your essay.
Provide evidence to support your arguments and ensure rigorous reasoning.
Obtain recommendation letters from teachers familiar with your research and writing abilities, if required.
Proofread carefully and follow all submission guidelines.
whatIsLookedFor: Students who show intellectual curiosity, strong analytical skills, creativity in argumentation, and the ability to communicate ideas effectively. The award values originality, critical thinking, and cross-disciplinary insight.

title: Lumiere Education Research Program
details: The Lumiere Individual Research Program is a paid, mentor-guided research opportunity for high school students globally. Participants engage in independent, in-depth research under the guidance of expert mentors from top universities. The program emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and research communication. Students produce a final research report, develop presentation skills, and gain experience in academic-style research methodology.
eligibility: Open to students in India (Standards IX–XII or equivalent) who are highly motivated to conduct independent research. Students must have strong critical thinking and writing skills. Prior research experience is beneficial but not required.
tips: Highlight your research interests and any prior independent projects.
we also offer financial aid and scholarship to our scholars.
Demonstrate your ability to work independently and manage time effectively.
Obtain strong recommendation letters from teachers familiar with your academic and research abilities.
Prepare a clear research proposal outlining your objectives, methods, and expected outcomes.
Show enthusiasm for the mentorship opportunity and readiness to engage in rigorous research.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with curiosity, initiative, analytical thinking, and the ability to conduct independent research. Lumiere values originality, persistence, and clarity in communication of research ideas.

title: Lumiere Junior Explorer Program
details: The Lumiere Junior Explorer Program is designed for middle school students who are eager to explore their academic interests and develop research and critical thinking skills. Students are paired with mentors from top universities who guide them through structured projects, helping them learn the basics of independent research, writing, and presentation. The program encourages curiosity and self-directed learning in a supportive environment.
eligibility: Open to middle school students (grades 6–8) worldwide who are interested in exploring research and academic enrichment.
tips: Highlight your curiosity and eagerness to explore new fields when applying.
Show genuine interest in learning rather than prior research experience.
Use the mentorship to build foundational skills for future academic programs.
whatIsLookedFor: The program values curiosity, openness to learning, and the willingness to engage in independent exploration and guided research.

title: Cambridge Future Scholars Program
details: The Cambridge Future Scholars Program is a paid, mentor-guided online research program for high school students globally. Participants engage in structured, in-depth research courses led by professors from top universities including Oxford, Cambridge, Harvard, MIT, Stanford, UPenn, Cornell, and Columbia. The program emphasizes critical thinking, academic writing, and research methodology. Students complete research projects, gain mentorship from PhD-level teaching assistants, and may have opportunities for publication or recognition. Financial aid is available on a case-by-case basis but the program is not fully free.
eligibility: Open to students in India (Standards IX–XII or equivalent) who are motivated to engage in structured research. Students should have strong academic and analytical skills. Prior research experience is beneficial but not required.
tips: Highlight your academic interests and any prior independent or school-based research projects.
Scholarships available. Highly competitive pool for financial aid. Need aware policy
Demonstrate critical thinking, organization, and time management skills.
Obtain recommendation letters from teachers familiar with your research or academic abilities.
Prepare a clear research plan outlining objectives, methodology, and expected outcomes.
Show enthusiasm for the mentorship and engagement with advanced academic research.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with strong curiosity, analytical skills, initiative, and the ability to conduct guided research. The program values critical thinking, originality, and clarity in research communication.

title: AoPS MIT PRIMES / CrowdMath
details: This program is an online collaborative mathematics research initiative for high school students, run by MIT PRIMES in partnership with Art of Problem Solving (AoPS). Participants work in small teams to solve open-ended research problems in areas like combinatorics, number theory, and algebra. Students gain experience with mathematical research, proof writing, and collaborative problem-solving.
eligibility: High school students with strong mathematical problem-solving skills, especially those experienced in advanced topics like combinatorics, algebra, and number theory.
tips: Familiarize yourself with mathematical research papers and problem-solving techniques.
Be proactive in team collaboration and communication.
Develop clear proof-writing and logical reasoning skills.
whatIsLookedFor: Mathematical creativity, teamwork, independent thinking, persistence, and ability to contribute to open-ended research problems.

title: GENIUS Olympiad
details: GENIUS Olympiad is an international high school project competition focused on environmental issues. Hosted by the Rochester Institute of Technology, students compete in eight disciplines including AI, Art, Coding, Entrepreneurship, Music, Robotics, Science, Short Film, and Speech. Participants develop projects that promote sustainability, raise awareness, and propose solutions to environmental challenges.
eligibility: High school students globally, individually or in teams, with a project addressing environmental issues in one of the GENIUS disciplines.
tips: Clearly define an environmental problem and your proposed solution.
Demonstrate creativity, research skills, and interdisciplinary thinking.
Prepare your project presentation thoroughly, including visual and/or performance components depending on the discipline.
whatIsLookedFor: Innovation, environmental awareness, scientific and artistic creativity, teamwork, and problem-solving skills.

title: Polymath Jr. – Collaborative Mathematical Research
details: Polymath Jr. provides undergraduate students with collaborative research opportunities in advanced mathematics. Participants work in small groups on research problems under the guidance of professional mathematicians, graduate students, and postdocs. The program encourages writing papers, exploring new mathematical ideas, and gaining mentorship experience.
eligibility: Undergraduate students with an interest in advanced mathematics and collaborative research.
tips: Be prepared to actively participate in research groups and collaborate with peers.
Demonstrate curiosity and motivation to tackle complex mathematical problems.
Familiarize yourself with research topics of interest to align with available projects.
whatIsLookedFor: Mathematical curiosity, problem-solving skills, teamwork, and readiness for research.

title: International Conference of Young Social Scientists (ICYSS) 2025
details: ICYSS is an international conference for high school students to engage in social science research, cultural exchange, and collaboration. Participants present research projects, attend workshops, and network with peers from around the world. The conference promotes learning about different cultures, creating friendships, and fostering interest in social sciences.
eligibility: High school students globally interested in social sciences and research projects.
tips: Prepare a well-researched social science project or paper.
Focus on clear presentation and communication of your research findings.
Be ready to engage with international peers and participate actively in workshops.
whatIsLookedFor: Research initiative, analytical thinking, curiosity about social sciences, and willingness to collaborate internationally.

title: Chegg.org Global Student Prize
details: The Chegg.org Global Student Prize recognizes outstanding students aged 16 and above who make a significant impact on learning, their peers, and society. Open to students worldwide, the prize highlights academic achievement, creativity, community impact, and global citizenship. The award selects a Top 50 shortlist, then Top 10 finalists, with one winner receiving $100,000.
eligibility: Students at least 16 years old enrolled in an academic institution, training, or skills program. Part-time and online students are eligible.
tips: Show measurable impact on your peers, community, or society.
Highlight academic achievements and innovative projects.
Demonstrate leadership, creativity, and global citizenship.
whatIsLookedFor: Impact, academic excellence, innovation, leadership, and contribution to society.

title: The Diana Award 2026
details: The Diana Award is a global honour recognising outstanding young people driving positive social change and humanitarian work. Recipients are celebrated for creating lasting impact aligned with Sustainable Development Goals such as Quality Education, Good Health & Wellbeing, Reducing Inequality, and Climate Action. The award highlights youth-led projects and initiatives across diverse communities worldwide.
eligibility: Young people aged 16–24 who have been leading sustained social action or humanitarian work for at least 12 months.
tips: Ensure your project or initiative demonstrates sustained social impact.
Highlight alignment with one or more SDGs: Education, Health, Inequality, or Climate Action.
Provide clear evidence of leadership, initiative, and positive change in the community.
whatIsLookedFor: Leadership, sustained social action, humanitarian impact, alignment with SDGs, and community contribution.

title: John Locke Institute Global Essay Prize
details: The John Locke Institute Global Essay Prize invites students worldwide to explore challenging questions across seven disciplines: Philosophy, Politics, Economics, History, Psychology, Theology, and Law. Essays are evaluated by senior academics from top universities, encouraging independent thought, critical analysis, and persuasive writing. A Junior Prize is also available for students under 15.
eligibility: Students worldwide aged 18 or younger (Junior Prize for students 14 or younger).
tips: Choose one question in your subject category and write an original, well-structured essay.
Ensure your essay demonstrates independent thought, depth of knowledge, and clear reasoning.
Provide an academic referee's email for verification of originality.
whatIsLookedFor: Independent thought, critical reasoning, depth of knowledge, persuasive writing, and originality.

title: Immerse Education Essay Competition 2026
details: Immerse Education’s Essay Competition offers students aged 13–18 the opportunity to engage in university-level academic writing across a wide range of subjects. Participants submit original essays online, evaluated by expert tutors from leading universities such as Oxford, Cambridge, and Ivy League institutions. Winners receive scholarships and recognition to support their academic development.
eligibility: Students aged 13–18 globally interested in developing university-level academic writing skills.
tips: Choose a topic you are passionate about and conduct thorough research.
Ensure your essay demonstrates critical thinking, originality, and clear argumentation.
Follow submission guidelines carefully and check for clarity, grammar, and structure.
whatIsLookedFor: Academic insight, originality, structured argumentation, clarity of thought, and engagement with the subject.

title: World Learning Youth Ambassadors Program 2026
details: The Youth Ambassadors Program brings together high school students and adult mentors across the Western Hemisphere to promote mutual understanding, develop leadership skills, and empower youth to make a difference in their communities. Participants engage in in-person or virtual exchanges, experiential learning, leadership trainings, civic participation, volunteering, and mentoring by community and NGO leaders.
eligibility: High school students from the Western Hemisphere with interest in leadership, civic engagement, and cultural exchange.
tips: Demonstrate leadership potential, community involvement, and initiative.
Be ready to actively engage in both experiential learning and mentoring activities.
Show cultural curiosity and willingness to collaborate with peers from diverse backgrounds.
whatIsLookedFor: Leadership, civic engagement, cultural awareness, collaboration, and commitment to community service.

title: HPAIR Harvard Conference 2026
details: The Harvard Conference (HCONF) by HPAIR unites global students, leaders, and professionals to discuss critical global challenges. The 34th conference theme, 'Emerging Horizons: Truth at Dawn, Hope at Dusk,' explores trust, resilience, and hope across communities. The conference features panels, workshops, keynote speeches, Executive Seminars, International Night (I-Night), and the Impact Challenge to foster cross-cultural understanding, leadership, and practical problem-solving skills.
eligibility: High school seniors and undergraduate students globally interested in leadership, global affairs, and cross-cultural engagement.
tips: Apply early to secure scholarships and early bird benefits.
Highlight leadership experience, community engagement, and interest in global issues.
Be prepared to actively participate in panels, workshops, and networking sessions.
whatIsLookedFor: Leadership potential, critical thinking, global awareness, cross-cultural engagement, and initiative.

title: Planet Forward Storyfest 2026
details: Planet Forward Storyfest is a student storytelling competition highlighting innovative solutions for environmental challenges. Students create written, video, or multimedia stories that inspire, inform, and motivate action on topics like climate justice, energy, food, water, biodiversity, public health, and the built environment. Selected stories receive recognition and winners may attend the Planet Forward Summit.
eligibility: Students globally, across all academic backgrounds, interested in environmental storytelling.
tips: Focus on originality, clarity, and impact of your story.
Use high-quality visuals or multimedia where applicable.
Align your story with one or more environmental or climate-related topics.
whatIsLookedFor: Creativity, originality, technical execution, clarity of message, environmental relevance, and storytelling impact.

title: RISE Summer Research Program
details: The Research in Science & Engineering (RISE) program at Boston University is a six-week summer program for high school juniors, offering hands-on laboratory research and computational projects. Students work alongside faculty, postdocs, and graduate students in areas like biology, chemistry, physics, computer science, neuroscience, biomedical engineering, and public health. The program includes workshops, company visits, and a Poster Symposium showcasing student research.
eligibility: High school juniors (domestic students) passionate about science and research. Committed to full six-week program.
tips: Prepare a strong statement of interest highlighting prior experience in STEM and research.
Be ready to work independently and collaboratively in a lab setting.
Show curiosity, initiative, and willingness to engage in computational or experimental research.
whatIsLookedFor: Research aptitude, curiosity, motivation, teamwork, technical skills, and commitment to full-time scientific research.

title: Secondary Student Training Program (SSTP)
details: SSTP is a highly selective and intensive summer research program for advanced high school students (grades 10–11). Participants conduct original research under mentorship from University of Iowa faculty, attend academic workshops, enhance their scholarly skills, and engage in seminars and collaborative activities. The program provides college credit and fosters meaningful connections with intellectual peers.
eligibility: High school students in grades 10–11 with strong academic performance and research interest. International students may apply with proof of English proficiency.
tips: Prepare strong essays highlighting research interests and career aspirations.
Provide clear academic and character references.
Demonstrate motivation, curiosity, and readiness for a full-time research experience.
whatIsLookedFor: Research aptitude, intellectual curiosity, motivation, academic excellence, and alignment with faculty research interests.

title: Inspirit AI Scholars Program
details: The Inspirit AI Scholars Program is a mentor-guided online program for high school students worldwide, developed and taught by Stanford and MIT alumni and graduate students. Participants work on socially impactful AI projects in small groups, exploring areas such as generative AI, precision medicine, exoplanet detection, AI for education, and ethical AI applications. The program emphasizes hands-on learning, collaboration, problem-solving, and preparation for future AI careers and college applications.
eligibility: Open to students in India currently in Standards IX–XII (or equivalent). No prior programming background is required, but interest in AI and problem-solving is recommended. Advanced cohorts are available for students with prior programming experience. Participants should have access to a computer with stable internet.
tips: Demonstrate interest in AI, computer science, or related fields.
students can request financial aid applications when applying to the program. They have limited financial assistance on a need basis.
Highlight any prior projects, competitions, or independent study in STEM or AI.
Obtain recommendation letters from teachers familiar with your technical and problem-solving abilities.
Show enthusiasm for socially impactful projects and mentorship.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with curiosity, problem-solving ability, and motivation to explore AI and technology for social impact. Inspirit values collaboration, creativity, persistence, and the willingness to learn from mentors and peers in a project-based environment.

title: Melton Foundation Global Solvers Accelerator 2026
details: The Global Solvers Accelerator is an 8-month peer-to-peer learning program for emerging social entrepreneurs worldwide. Participants refine and grow their social impact projects, develop leadership capacity, and collaborate with a global cohort of changemakers. The program includes virtual modules, personalized support, and a fully funded week-long in-person Co-Lab in Accra, Ghana, culminating in lifelong membership in the Melton Fellowship network.
eligibility: Emerging social entrepreneurs aged 20–35 with a proven track record in social impact and active leadership of a community project.
tips: Highlight your social impact project and measurable outcomes.
Demonstrate leadership, commitment, and curiosity to learn.
Show readiness to collaborate with international peers and embrace transformative change.
whatIsLookedFor: Social impact experience, leadership potential, commitment to SDGs, collaboration, and transformative thinking.

title: The Queen’s Commonwealth Essay Competition 2026
details: The Queen’s Commonwealth Essay Competition, established in 1883, is the world’s oldest international writing competition for schools. It invites young people across the Commonwealth to explore topics related to journeys, culture, and personal or historical experiences. The competition develops writing skills, critical thinking, and creativity, and provides recognition for outstanding essays.
eligibility: Students across the Commonwealth, typically aged 14–18.
tips: Reflect on the given theme creatively and personally.
Focus on clarity, originality, and engagement in your writing.
Follow the submission guidelines carefully and proofread thoroughly.
whatIsLookedFor: Originality, creativity, critical thinking, clarity of expression, and relevance to the theme.

title: New York Times Student Online Competitions
details: The New York Times Student Online Competitions provide creative opportunities for middle and high school students to engage with writing, journalism, and multimedia. Students can participate in editorials, narrative essays, educational podcasts, photo essays, and other contests. Highlights include the Student Conversation Forum on the U.S. Elections and other multimedia competitions. Winners gain recognition and may have their work published on The New York Times Learning Network.
eligibility: Current middle and high school students.
tips: Follow the specific competition guidelines carefully.
Focus on clarity, originality, and relevance to the theme.
Engage with current events or social issues creatively and thoughtfully.
whatIsLookedFor: Originality, creativity, engagement with the topic, clarity in writing or multimedia presentation, and critical thinking.

title: Wharton Global Youth Investment Competition 2026
details: The Wharton Global Youth Investment Competition offers high school students a hands-on experience in investment and financial decision-making. Participants work in teams to analyze markets, manage virtual portfolios, and develop investment strategies. The program includes educational resources, case studies, and mentorship from Wharton faculty, culminating in a global showcase of student projects.
eligibility: High school students globally, individually or in teams, interested in finance, investment, and business analytics.
tips: Collaborate effectively within your team and assign roles based on strengths.
Understand financial markets and research investment opportunities thoroughly.
Leverage provided learning resources and case studies to inform your strategy.
whatIsLookedFor: Analytical skills, teamwork, financial acumen, creativity in investment strategy, and presentation skills.

title: Scholastic Art & Writing Awards 2026
details: The Scholastic Art & Writing Awards, organized by the Alliance for Young Artists & Writers, is the nation’s longest-running recognition program for creative teens. Students in grades 7–12 (ages 13 and up) can submit original works in 28 categories of visual and literary arts. Winners are celebrated through exhibitions, publications, and national ceremonies, and may be eligible for scholarships of up to $12,500.
eligibility: Students in grades 7–12 (ages 13 and up) worldwide.
tips: Submit original work demonstrating creativity and technical skill.
Choose a category that best fits your work for a stronger evaluation.
Ensure your submission follows all guidelines and deadlines for consideration.
whatIsLookedFor: Creativity, originality, technical skill, and engagement with the chosen category.

title: SPARC Summer Program
details: SPARC (Summer Program for Applied Rationality and Cognition) is a free, intensive program for talented high school students to develop advanced quantitative skills and apply them to real-world problems. The program emphasizes experiential learning through small, discussion-based classes, programming labs, self-reflection, and interactions with academics, CEOs, and philanthropists. Participants explore undergraduate and graduate-level concepts in areas like causal modeling and cognitive science, while connecting their learning to practical applications.
eligibility: High school students with strong quantitative aptitude and interest in cognitive science, rationality, and applied mathematics.
tips: Demonstrate strong quantitative and analytical skills in your application.
Show motivation to apply learning to real-world problems.
Be prepared for active participation, discussion, and self-reflection.
whatIsLookedFor: Quantitative aptitude, curiosity, creativity, motivation, collaborative mindset, and eagerness to apply skills to practical challenges.

title: MathWorks Math Modeling Challenge (M³ Challenge) 2026
details: The M³ Challenge is an internet-based math modeling competition where high school teams solve real-world, open-ended problems over a 14-hour weekend. Teams of 3–5 students from the U.S., England, and Wales participate in developing solutions using mathematical modeling, analysis, and optionally MATLAB. Top teams receive scholarship awards and may travel to NYC to present their work.
eligibility: High school students in the U.S., England, and Wales; teams of 3–5 students.
tips: Form a balanced team with complementary skills in math, coding, and writing.
Review sample problems and resources provided on the official site.
Plan your 14-hour work session carefully, manage time, and divide responsibilities.
whatIsLookedFor: Teamwork, mathematical modeling skills, problem-solving, clear presentation of results, and creativity.
deadline: Registration opens November 2025; exact Challenge weekend dates to be announced

title: NASA International Space Apps Challenge 2025
details: The NASA International Space Apps Challenge is a global hackathon that invites coders, scientists, designers, and storytellers to solve space-related challenges. Participants use open data provided by NASA and its Space Agency Partners to work in teams of 1–6 members to create innovative solutions. Each year focuses on a specific theme. Winning teams are recognized with invitations to a Winners Celebration at a NASA center to engage with NASA leaders and showcase their solutions.
eligibility: Open to all ages. Participants under 18 must be registered and accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
tips: Form a diverse team with complementary skills in coding, design, and research.
Familiarize yourself with NASA’s open data and resources in advance.
Focus on innovative, practical, and scalable solutions to the challenge theme.
whatIsLookedFor: Innovation, teamwork, creativity, technical skill, and applicability of solutions to space-related challenges.

title: Canadian Computing Competition (CCC) 2026
details: The Canadian Computing Competition (CCC) is a programming contest for secondary school students. It offers both Junior and Senior levels, challenging participants with problems that range from basic loops and conditions to IOI-level algorithms. Participants write solutions online in languages like C, C++, Python, or Java. The contest helps students develop problem-solving, algorithmic thinking, and programming skills.
eligibility: High school students; participants choose Junior or Senior level regardless of grade.
tips: Practice using the CCC Online Grader and review past contests.
Choose the level (Junior or Senior) that best matches your programming skills.
Familiarize yourself with problem-solving strategies for algorithms and data structures.
whatIsLookedFor: Problem-solving skills, algorithmic thinking, programming proficiency, and logical reasoning.
programDates: North & South America: February 18, 2026 | Outside Americas: February 19, 2026

title: International Biology Olympiad (IBO)
details: The International Biology Olympiad (IBO) is the world’s largest biology competition for secondary school students. It takes place annually in July in different host countries and lasts one week. Participants are selected through their National Biology Olympiad (NBO) and compete in theoretical and practical biology challenges at an international level.
eligibility: High school students who win their National Biology Olympiad and are selected to represent their country or region.
tips: Participate and excel in your National Biology Olympiad to qualify.
Develop strong theoretical knowledge and practical lab skills in biology.
Practice previous IBO tasks and exams to prepare for international-level challenges.
whatIsLookedFor: Strong biology knowledge, laboratory skills, problem-solving, analytical thinking, and teamwork.

title: Regeneron Science Talent Search 2026
details: The Regeneron Science Talent Search (STS) is the nation’s oldest and most prestigious science research competition for high school students. Students submit original research projects in STEM fields for holistic review. Around 2,500 students apply annually, with the top 300 scholars, top 40 finalists, and eventual winners recognized for their scientific innovation and leadership. Finalists participate in STS Finals Week, presenting projects and attending an awards ceremony.
eligibility: High school seniors in the U.S.; international students may apply through affiliated programs.
tips: Submit original, well-documented research with clear societal relevance.
Demonstrate scientific rigor, creativity, and innovation.
Include a compelling personal statement, recommendation letters, and academic records.
whatIsLookedFor: Scientific innovation, analytical skills, creativity, research impact, and leadership potential.
programDates: Application Period: June 1 – November 6, 2025 | Top 300 Scholars: Jan 7, 2026 | Top 40 Finalists: Jan 21, 2026 | Finals Week: March 5–11, 2026 | Awards Ceremony: March 10, 2026

title: Global Case Competition (HCGCC) 2025
details: The Global Case Competition (HCGCC) is a virtual competition for ambitious high school students aged 13–18. Participants work in teams of 2–4 to tackle real-world business challenges, step into the shoes of CEOs or consultants, and present solutions to a panel of judges. The program includes on-demand bootcamps and live webinars with industry experts to develop skills in strategy, finance, design, and creativity. Top teams can win cash prizes, virtual work experiences at Fortune 500 companies, and educational consulting prizes.
eligibility: High school students aged 13–18, enrolled in school or recently graduated, working in teams of 2–4 students.
tips: Form a team with complementary skills in research, presentation, and strategy.
Participate in webinars and bootcamps to strengthen your business knowledge.
Start your pitchdeck early and practice the Q&A session thoroughly.
whatIsLookedFor: Creativity, teamwork, strategic thinking, problem-solving, and clear presentation skills.
programDates: Registrations: Jul 14 – Oct 15, 2025 | Regional Qualifiers: Oct 16 – Nov 7, 2025 | Global Finals: Nov 30, 2025

title: Blue Ocean High School Entrepreneurship Competition 2026
details: The Blue Ocean High School Entrepreneurship Competition is the largest and most prestigious pitch competition for high school students worldwide. Participants, individually or in teams of up to 5, pitch innovative business ideas virtually to experienced entrepreneurs and business leaders, receive feedback, and compete for cash prizes and school awards. Students create a 5-minute video pitch according to the provided rubric and submit it online.
eligibility: High school students worldwide; participants may work alone or in teams of up to 5 students.
tips: Develop a clear, innovative, and practical business idea.
Use the official pitch rubric from the Resources page to structure your video.
Engage creatively in your presentation to impress judges and maximize impact.
whatIsLookedFor: Innovation, clarity of pitch, business viability, creativity, teamwork, and presentation skills.

title: NFTE Impact League / World Series of Innovation (WSI) 2025
details: The NFTE Impact League, part of the World Series of Innovation, is a global entrepreneurship competition for students aged 13–24. Participants, individually or in teams, tackle challenge briefs aligned with UN Sustainable Development Goals to create impactful solutions. Competitors submit innovative ideas via an online platform, receive feedback, and top entries advance to final judging with live virtual events and prizes.
eligibility: Students aged 13–24; may participate individually or in teams.
tips: Select a challenge that aligns with your interests and creativity.
Use the Innovators Tool Kit and rubric to structure your submission.
Focus on impact, creativity, feasibility, and presentation of your solution.
whatIsLookedFor: Creativity, innovation, social impact, clarity of idea, and entrepreneurial thinking.

title: Harvard Crimson Business Competition (HCBC) 2026
details: The Harvard Crimson Business Competition is a global competition for middle and high school students to showcase their innovation and business acumen. Students work individually or in teams to develop sustainable business plans addressing global challenges, receive guidance from Harvard alumni and The Harvard Crimson, and compete in preliminary and championship rounds with top participants invited to Harvard University.
eligibility: Middle and high school students worldwide; participants can compete solo or in teams (Preliminary Round: 3–8 members, Championship Round: 3–4 members).
tips: Choose a global challenge that inspires you and aligns with your skills.
Develop a sustainable, practical business plan with clear research and analysis.
Practice presenting your ideas effectively for judges and online submission.
whatIsLookedFor: Innovation, problem-solving, business acumen, creativity, teamwork, and clarity of presentation.

title: Harvard Crimson Global Essay Competition (HCGEC) 2026
details: The Harvard Crimson Global Essay Competition (HCGEC) is a fully virtual, global writing challenge for ambitious high school students. Hosted by The Harvard Crimson, it allows participants to refine writing skills, explore different writing styles, gain international recognition, and strengthen university applications. Participants attend workshops and bootcamps, compete online, and have the chance for publication and exclusive prizes.
eligibility: High school students worldwide; participants must register online to compete.
tips: Attend the provided bootcamps and webinars to strengthen your writing.
Follow the competition’s guidelines for university-level essay writing.
Focus on originality, clarity, and persuasive communication.
whatIsLookedFor: Writing proficiency, creativity, clarity of expression, critical thinking, and engagement with the essay topic.

title: JASNA Annual Essay Contest 2026
details: The Jane Austen Society of North America (JASNA) conducts an annual essay contest to encourage the study and appreciation of Jane Austen’s works. Students worldwide are invited to submit essays analyzing Austen's novels, characters, motifs, or themes. Winners receive scholarships, publication opportunities, and membership in JASNA.
eligibility: High school, undergraduate, and graduate students worldwide. Membership in JASNA is not required.
tips: Follow essay guidelines carefully and address the chosen prompt thoroughly.
Use quotations from Austen’s texts to support your analysis.
Ensure clarity, originality, and depth in your interpretation.
whatIsLookedFor: Analytical thinking, understanding of Jane Austen’s works, originality, clarity of writing, and adherence to guidelines.

title: JFK Library Profile in Courage Essay Contest 2026
details: The JFK Library Profile in Courage Essay Contest invites high school students to write an original essay about an elected official who has demonstrated political courage. The contest encourages critical thinking, research, and writing skills while celebrating acts of leadership and integrity. Winners receive scholarships and the opportunity to be recognized nationally.
eligibility: High school students in the United States; students must submit original essays of 700–1,000 words.
tips: Select an elected official who demonstrated true political courage.
Use credible sources to support your essay with historical evidence.
Ensure clarity, originality, and adherence to the word limit.
whatIsLookedFor: Analytical thinking, clarity, historical accuracy, originality, and demonstration of political courage.

title: EngineerGirl Writing Contest 2023: Better Great Achievements
details: The EngineerGirl Writing Contest invites students to write about how female and/or non-white engineers have contributed to or can enhance engineering’s great achievements. Participants explore 20 major engineering accomplishments of the 20th century, reflect on diversity in engineering, and propose innovative solutions for the 21st century. Essays are evaluated on presentation of engineering, celebration of diversity, and quality of writing.
eligibility: Students in grades 3–12; submissions may be individual or part of a class project.
tips: Choose one of the 20 Greatest Engineering Achievements of the 20th Century as your topic.
Highlight contributions from female and/or non-white engineers.
Use APA citation style for references and stay within the word limits for your grade level.
whatIsLookedFor: Understanding of engineering, creativity, appreciation of diversity, quality of writing, and adherence to guidelines.

title: Ayn Rand Institute Anthem Essay Contest 2026
details: The Anthem Essay Contest, hosted by the Ayn Rand Institute, invites middle and high school students worldwide to write essays on Ayn Rand’s novel 'Anthem.' Participants explore themes of individualism, freedom, and human potential. Essays are evaluated on understanding of the text, clarity, creativity, and philosophical insight. Winners receive scholarship prizes up to $25,000 and gain recognition for intellectual engagement and writing excellence.
eligibility: Middle and high school students worldwide, ages 13 and older; participants must be enrolled in school during the contest period.
tips: Read 'Anthem' carefully and take notes on themes, characters, and key passages.
Demonstrate understanding of Ayn Rand’s philosophy and its application to the essay prompt.
Ensure clarity, originality, and strong reasoning in your essay.
whatIsLookedFor: Comprehension of the novel, analytical thinking, creativity, philosophical insight, and quality of writing.

title: Princeton Ten-Minute Play Contest 2026
details: The Princeton Ten-Minute Play Contest is an annual playwriting competition for high school juniors (11th grade) in the U.S. and international equivalents. Students submit original plays of up to 10 pages (1 page = 1 minute). Each year, a guest playwright judges the contest. Winning plays receive cash prizes and recognition.
eligibility: Students in 11th grade in the U.S. or the international equivalent; home-schooled students at this level are also eligible.
tips: Submit only one play per student or team.
Keep your play under 10 pages.
Focus on originality and clarity; any theme is allowed.
Collaborative plays are allowed if all authors are eligible; prizes are shared.
whatIsLookedFor: Creativity, originality, clarity of storytelling, and adherence to playwriting format.

title: Leonard L. Milberg ’53 High School Poetry Prize 2026
details: The Leonard L. Milberg ’53 High School Poetry Prize recognizes outstanding poetry by 11th grade students in the U.S. or internationally. Entries are judged by Princeton University creative writing faculty. Students can submit up to three poems, including translations of their own non-English poems. Winners receive cash prizes and recognition.
eligibility: 11th grade students in the U.S. or abroad, including home-schooled students; multiple poems allowed up to three.
tips: Submit your strongest original poems, up to three.
If submitting poems in another language, include your own English translation.
Focus on originality, clarity, and creative expression.
whatIsLookedFor: Creativity, originality, quality of poetic expression, and adherence to submission guidelines.

title: The Blank Young Playwrights Festival (YPF) 2026
details: The Blank Young Playwrights Festival is an annual competition for young playwrights to have their original plays or musicals professionally mentored, directed, and performed. Participants gain feedback from professional theater artists, opportunities to develop their scripts, and experience in a real theatrical production setting.
eligibility: Playwrights 19 years or younger as of March 15, 2026, residing or attending school in the U.S.; co-authored plays allowed if all authors meet eligibility requirements.
tips: Submit original plays or musicals of any length or genre; no AI-generated content is allowed.
Ensure your script has a title page and numbered pages.
You may submit up to three plays, each with a separate submission form.
whatIsLookedFor: Originality, creativity, theatrical potential, and quality of writing.

title: Yale Daily News Journalism Competition 2026
details: The Yale Daily News Journalism Competition is an annual contest for high school students to showcase their journalistic skills. Participants submit original reporting, feature writing, opinion pieces, or multimedia journalism projects. The competition aims to encourage student writers to develop their voice, improve journalistic techniques, and gain recognition for their work.
eligibility: High school students worldwide; individual submissions only.
tips: Focus on originality, clarity, and journalistic integrity.
Ensure proper sourcing and fact-checking in all submissions.
Follow the submission guidelines and deadlines carefully.
whatIsLookedFor: Accuracy, creativity, clarity, newsworthiness, and quality of writing.

title: Zero Robotics High School Tournament 2026
details: Zero Robotics is a robotics programming competition where high school teams program Astrobee robots aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Teams first develop code online using the Zero Robotics IDE to solve annual coding challenges. Finalists get to test their programs live on the ISS, with an astronaut conducting the competition in microgravity. The tournament encourages coding, teamwork, and problem-solving in a real-world space environment.
eligibility: High school students (grades 9–12) based in the United States; teams of 5–20 students with a mentor. Future expansion to international participants is planned.
tips: Form a balanced team with strong programming and problem-solving skills.
Familiarize yourself with the Zero Robotics IDE and past challenge games.
Focus on creating autonomous programs that efficiently solve the objectives of the game.
whatIsLookedFor: Coding proficiency, teamwork, strategic thinking, creativity, and ability to optimize autonomous robot programs.

title: Spellman HV Clean Tech Competition 2026
details: The Spellman HV Clean Tech Competition is a global sustainability innovation competition for high school students. Participants, in teams of 1–3 with an adult mentor, research and propose innovative solutions to environmental challenges, such as ocean cleanup or water filtration. Submissions include a 5–15 page research paper, scored on scientific method, technological innovation, and engineering design. Top teams present virtually and compete for cash prizes.
eligibility: High school students aged 15–18; teams of 1–3 students with an adult team leader (19+).
tips: Use the scientific method rigorously in your research paper.
Focus on innovative, practical, and sustainable solutions.
Pay attention to engineering design and identify potential challenges with solutions.
whatIsLookedFor: Scientific rigor, creativity, engineering design, feasibility, and impact on sustainability.

title: Citizen Entrepreneurship Competition (CEC) 2026
details: The Citizen Entrepreneurship Competition (CEC) empowers young entrepreneurs worldwide to submit innovative ideas with social impact. Participants develop projects aligned with one or more of the 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), complete online courses, refine their Entrepreneurial Design Canvas (EDC), and compete in three phases: idea submission, public voting, and expert jury selection. Winners are announced in an online award ceremony, and all participants gain access to a global community of like-minded innovators.
eligibility: Entrepreneurs aged 13 and above; global participation allowed.
tips: Align your idea with one or more UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
Use the Entrepreneurial Design Canvas (EDC) to structure and refine your idea.
Engage with the global online community for feedback and collaboration.
whatIsLookedFor: Innovation, social impact, creativity, commitment to SDGs, and entrepreneurial thinking.
deadline: Check the official website for current year submission deadlines

title: High School Academic Research Competition (SARC)
details: The High School Academic Research Competition (HSARC) is an international research competition designed to provide high school students the opportunity to showcase their academic research across disciplines. Students submit original research papers, which are evaluated by expert judges. The competition emphasizes critical thinking, originality, depth of research, and clarity of academic writing. Top submissions receive recognition, awards, and opportunities to present their work.
eligibility: Open to high school students worldwide (Grades 9–12 or equivalent). Students must submit an original academic research paper in any discipline. Collaborative submissions are allowed if all contributors are in high school.
tips: Select a topic that reflects your genuine interest and academic curiosity.
The cost of registration is very minimal. Application fee discount codes are available.
Ensure your research proposal has a clear thesis, strong evidence, and proper citations.
Demonstrate originality in your research approach or argument.
Follow academic writing conventions carefully, including structure and style.
Revise and proofread your work thoroughly before submission.
whatIsLookedFor: HSARC values originality, academic rigor, clarity of writing, and innovative approaches to research. Judges look for students who can demonstrate both depth and breadth of understanding in their chosen subject.

title: Ross Mathematics Program
details: The Ross Program is a 6-week intensive summer program for motivated pre-college students to explore mathematics deeply. Students engage in problem-solving, mathematical discovery, and collaborative learning in a supportive environment. The program nurtures mathematical curiosity, logical thinking, and critical reasoning skills, preparing students for advanced studies in mathematics, science, finance, and other analytical fields.
eligibility: Pre-college students with strong interest and aptitude in mathematics, typically entering grades 10–12.
tips: Engage deeply with challenging mathematical problems.
Show commitment and enthusiasm for collaborative learning.
Prepare a strong application highlighting previous math experience and problem-solving skills.
whatIsLookedFor: Mathematical talent, curiosity, logical reasoning, perseverance, and collaborative spirit.

title: Science Internship Program (SIP) — UCSC
details: The Science Internship Program (SIP) at UC Santa Cruz offers high school students the chance to engage in authentic, open-ended research. The program begins with an online preparatory week and then moves into in-person research under UCSC faculty and mentors. Research areas span science, engineering, social sciences, humanities, and art. SIP encourages equity and supports need-based scholarships. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
eligibility: Students must be enrolled in high school and at least 14 years old by program start. Graduated high school students are typically ineligible. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
tips: Show strong genuine interest in your research area and how you intend to learn.
Emphasize ability to manage independent work and communicate with mentors.
Highlight any STEM coursework, projects or self-directed learning you’ve done.
whatIsLookedFor: SIP seeks students with curiosity, resilience, self-motivation, and preparedness to contribute in real research settings. Strong academic performance, commitment to science, and clear thinking in essays strengthen applications. Prior research experience helps but is not mandatory. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

title: Vidyarthi Vigyan Manthan (VVM) Science Contest
details: Vidyarthi Vigyan Manthan (VVM) is India’s largest online science talent search for students of grades VI to XI, aimed at creating awareness in science, fostering excellence, and identifying students with scientific aptitude. The international edition, Śāstra Pratibhā Contest, is organized in collaboration with NCERT, NCSM, and other bodies. The contest spans multiple levels including objective tests, writing, practicals, and presentations.
eligibility: Students from grades VI to XI in participating countries may register. The international edition (Śāstra Pratibhā) is open to GCC countries as well.
tips: Regularly practice multiple-choice science and reasoning questions.
Work on speed and accuracy in solving questions under timed conditions.
Read up on basic concepts in physics, chemistry, biology, and mathematics beyond the school curriculum.
whatIsLookedFor: Strong aptitude for science, quick analytical thinking, consistency in performance, and clarity in writing and conceptual understanding.

title: NASA Human Exploration Rover Challenge
details: The NASA Human Exploration Rover Challenge is an annual competition for high school and college students to design, build, and race human-powered rovers simulating exploration on the Moon or Mars. Teams tackle engineering design, problem-solving, and teamwork challenges across obstacle courses replicating extraterrestrial terrain.
eligibility: Open to high school and college teams internationally, typically comprising 3–6 students per team.
tips: Focus on rover design optimization for weight and maneuverability.
Practice teamwork and communication during rover construction and testing.
Familiarize with basic mechanical engineering and materials science concepts.
whatIsLookedFor: Creativity, problem-solving, engineering skill, teamwork, and performance under challenging conditions.

title: Lodha Genius Programme Ashoka University
details: The Lodha Genius Programme is a fully funded, multi-year educational initiative by the Lodha Foundation in partnership with Ashoka University. Designed for exceptional students from Grade 9 through their early career, the programme offers immersive science and mathematics courses, practical life skills lessons, sustained mentorship, and exclusive access to prestigious internship opportunities. Students engage in a four-week campus experience at Ashoka University, complemented by year-round continued learning and mentorship.
eligibility: Open to students currently in Grade 9–11 across India, exhibiting academic excellence, leadership qualities, and a passion for continuous learning. The programme complements all major examination boards.
tips: Demonstrate a strong aptitude in science and mathematics.
Showcase leadership skills and a commitment to personal growth.
Highlight any extracurricular activities or projects that reflect your passion for learning.
whatIsLookedFor: The programme seeks self-motivated, ambitious students with a keen interest in science and mathematics. Applicants should exhibit problem-solving abilities, creativity, and a desire to contribute to society.

title: Wolfram Summer Research Program
