details: A program designed for high school students to engage in research using Wolfram technologies. Students learn to apply computational thinking, data analysis, and mathematical modeling to real-world research problems, mentored by experts and guided through structured projects.
eligibility: High school students worldwide, typically grades 9–12, interested in computational research and STEM.
tips: Familiarize yourself with Wolfram Language and Wolfram|Alpha functionalities.
Practice computational thinking and basic programming concepts.
Prepare a clear research idea or area of interest before applying.
whatIsLookedFor: Curiosity in computational research, problem-solving skills, motivation to learn, and ability to work on complex projects independently or in small teams.

title: Non-Trivial Online Research Programs
details: Non-Trivial offers a sequence of online programs for students aged 14–20 to conduct impactful original research. Programs take students from foundational research skills to leading original projects with mentorship from experts. Stages include Research Foundations, Research Fellows, and Research Scholars, each with increasing responsibility, mentorship, and potential scholarships.
eligibility: Students aged 14–20 worldwide. Programs are designed to progress from learning research fundamentals to conducting original research.
tips: Focus on generating original research ideas and refining your question.
Engage actively with mentors and ask for feedback.
Manage your time effectively across program stages and meet deadlines for projects.
whatIsLookedFor: Curiosity, creativity, ability to conduct original research, problem-solving skills, and commitment to completing rigorous projects.

title: Monroe University JumpStart Program
details: The JumpStart Program at Monroe University allows high school juniors and seniors to take college-level courses, either on-campus or online, earning college credits that are transferable to other institutions. The program provides a head start on college education and exposure to university-level academics.
eligibility: Open to high school juniors and seniors interested in earning college credits before graduation.
tips: Choose courses aligned with your intended college major or interests.
Stay disciplined with college-level coursework and time management.
Engage with professors and peers to maximize learning and networking opportunities.
whatIsLookedFor: Academic readiness, motivation to take college-level courses, and commitment to completing coursework successfully.

title: New York Academic of Sciences (NYAS) Junior Academy
details: The Junior Academy is a project-based learning program connecting students ages 13–17 with an online community of peers and STEM mentors. Students collaborate on real-world innovation challenges, develop critical thinking and research skills, and gain experience in STEM problem-solving through the Launchpad platform.
eligibility: Students aged 13–17 worldwide. Strong English proficiency required. Enthusiastic learners passionate about STEM and collaboration.
tips: Engage actively with mentors and peers for guidance and collaboration.
Manage your time carefully to meet challenge milestones and deadlines.
Focus on developing innovative solutions and clear presentations for your projects.
whatIsLookedFor: Curiosity, problem-solving skills, collaboration, creativity, and ability to work independently on research challenges.

title: Math ExpLR Summer Research Program
details: The NSF-Simons Center for Multiscale Cell Fate Research at UC Irvine invites high school students to participate in a 6-week summer research program in computational biology. Students work in small teams with a PI on projects, attend skill-building workshops on Matlab, mathematical modeling, research presentations, and writing a research paper. Most activities are in-person, and the program is free to apply and participate.
eligibility: Current high school students (grades 9–11). Middle school students and graduating seniors are not eligible.
tips: Familiarize yourself with Matlab and basic mathematical modeling.
Work on presenting your research clearly and writing concise reports.
Collaborate effectively in small research teams.
whatIsLookedFor: Interest in computational biology, problem-solving skills, ability to work in a team, and willingness to learn and apply computational techniques to research.

title: Aspiring Scientists Summer Internship Program (ASSIP)
details: ASSIP provides transformative research opportunities for high school and undergraduate students. Participants work one-on-one with faculty researchers at George Mason University and collaborating institutions, using state-of-the-art technology across disciplines such as astronomy, biochemistry, environmental science, computer science, neuroscience, robotics, climate science, and more. Interns gain hands-on research experience, scientific writing skills, and exposure to STEM careers.
eligibility: High school students aged 15+ for remote/in-person computer labs, 16+ for wet-lab internships. Must not have graduated from university before or during the internship.
tips: Prepare to articulate your research interests and prior experiences.
Focus on developing both technical and scientific communication skills.
Be proactive in seeking guidance from mentors and collaborating effectively in research teams.
whatIsLookedFor: Curiosity, creativity, motivation, research aptitude, problem-solving skills, and commitment to completing rigorous projects.

title: Summer Science Research Program (SSRP)
details: SSRP is a team-based mentored research program for high school juniors and seniors at Rockefeller University. Students work in research teams guided by scientific trainees from the Tri-Institutions (Rockefeller, MSK, WCMC) and gain hands-on experience in laboratory research, elective courses, workshops, guest lectures, and networking events.
eligibility: High school juniors and seniors, aged 16+ at program start, must commit to the full seven-week program.
tips: Prepare a clear statement of research interest and past experiences.
Be ready to work full-time in a lab and collaborate effectively in teams.
Develop skills in scientific writing and presenting research findings.
whatIsLookedFor: Curiosity, motivation, research aptitude, teamwork, and commitment to a full-time mentored research experience.

title: UPenn Management & Technology Summer Institute (M&TSI)
details: M&TSI is a rigorous, for-credit summer program for rising high school seniors to explore the integration of technology and management. Students take courses taught by Wharton and Penn Engineering faculty, participate in an intensive team prototyping project, develop a go-to-market plan, and receive feedback from entrepreneurs and investors. The program includes simulations, guest lectures, and awards a full college credit upon completion.
eligibility: Rising high school seniors. International applicants and students seeking financial aid are encouraged to apply by the priority deadline.
tips: Prepare a strong application highlighting academic achievements and leadership in extracurricular activities.
Be ready for intensive, fast-paced coursework and team projects.
Engage proactively with peers and faculty for mentorship and feedback.
whatIsLookedFor: Academic excellence, leadership, motivation, creativity, teamwork, and commitment to a rigorous summer program.

title: Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youth (CTY) Programs
details: CTY offers advanced academic programs for students in grades 2–12, providing rigorous courses, personalized instruction, and a community of peers. Programs include online courses, on-campus summer programs, and talent search assessments to identify and nurture gifted students. Students can accelerate learning, explore subjects in-depth, and gain enrichment beyond school curricula.
eligibility: Students in grades 2–12 worldwide. Admission often requires above-grade-level testing through CTY Talent Search.
tips: Select courses that challenge your current level and align with your interests.
Engage actively with instructors and peers in online and on-campus programs.
Plan ahead to balance program workload with school and extracurricular commitments.
whatIsLookedFor: Intellectual curiosity, motivation, academic readiness, and a willingness to engage with challenging material.

title: Raising A Mathematician (RAM) Foundation Programs
details: RAM Foundation is a not-for-profit organization in India dedicated to identifying and nurturing mathematical talents. They offer residential and online camps, courses, and mentorship programs for students preparing for Mathematics and Informatics Olympiads. Programs include exposure to advanced mathematical concepts, problem-solving, competitions, and community building for students, parents, and educators.
eligibility: Students from grades 4 to 12 with interest and aptitude in mathematics and informatics. Selection-based for most programs.
tips: Focus on developing strong problem-solving and logical reasoning skills.
Engage with advanced math topics beyond school curriculum.
Participate actively in mentorship and peer learning opportunities.
whatIsLookedFor: Mathematical curiosity, problem-solving ability, motivation, creativity, and commitment to learning advanced mathematics.

title: Garcia Center Research Scholar Program for High School Students
details: The Garcia Center pre-college program allows high school students to engage in polymer science research alongside Garcia faculty and staff. Students work in focused research teams, contribute original findings, participate in national competitions, and are encouraged to publish in scientific journals and present at conferences. The program aims to convey the excitement of polymer research and provide long-term mentorship.
eligibility: High school students and teachers interested in polymer science research. Students work in teams with faculty mentorship.
tips: Develop a strong interest in materials science and research.
Be prepared to contribute original ideas and work collaboratively.
Engage in scientific writing and presentations for competitions and conferences.
whatIsLookedFor: Curiosity, teamwork, research aptitude, creativity, and motivation to contribute to scientific projects.

title: IITM Pravartak Out-of-Box Thinking Program
details: A program designed to foster creativity, innovation, and problem-solving skills among students. Participants engage in workshops, collaborative challenges, and design thinking exercises to develop practical solutions to real-world problems.
eligibility: High school students with interest in science, technology, and creative problem-solving.
tips: Practice creative problem-solving and brainstorming skills.
Work on teamwork and presenting ideas clearly.
Engage in exercises that challenge conventional thinking and explore innovative solutions.
whatIsLookedFor: Creativity, analytical thinking, collaboration, motivation, and ability to think beyond standard solutions.

title: Berggruen Prize Essay Competition
details: The Berggruen Prize Essay Competition is an annual contest that encourages innovative thinking and cross-cultural perspectives. Participants submit essays addressing fundamental philosophical questions relevant to contemporary life and the future. Winning essays are awarded prizes and published, highlighting diverse global viewpoints.
eligibility: Open to individuals interested in philosophy, culture, and innovative ideas. Essays can be submitted in English or Chinese.
tips: Focus on presenting a novel, clearly argued idea.
Read and study classic and contemporary philosophical essays for inspiration.
Emphasize clarity, creativity, and cross-cultural perspectives in your writing.
whatIsLookedFor: Original thinking, intellectual rigor, clarity of expression, creativity, and the ability to present compelling philosophical arguments.

title: International Research Olympiad (IRO)
details: The International Research Olympiad (IRO) is a global platform for high school students to present and showcase original research across multiple disciplines. Participants submit their research projects and compete at an international level, gaining feedback from expert judges and opportunities for recognition. The Olympiad emphasizes innovation, problem-solving, and the ability to communicate complex ideas effectively through written work and presentations.
eligibility: Open to high school students worldwide (Grades 9–12 or equivalent). Applicants must submit an original research project or paper in any discipline. Both individual and team submissions are accepted.
tips: Choose a research topic that demonstrates originality and global relevance.
The International Research Olympiad (IRO) has a registration fee of $25 USD.
Ensure your submission is well-structured, with a clear research question, methodology, and conclusion.
Showcase creativity and problem-solving in approaching your research.
Practice communicating your ideas effectively for presentations and interviews.
Pay close attention to formatting, citations, and academic rigor.
whatIsLookedFor: The Olympiad values originality, depth of research, clarity in communication, and the ability to address real-world issues through innovative approaches. Judges look for both strong academic content and effective presentation skills.

title: MathILy Summer Program
details: MathILy is an intensive, five-week residential summer program for mathematically talented high school students. The program emphasizes creative problem-solving, exploration of advanced mathematics, and collaborative learning. Students engage in writing proofs, solving challenging problems, and developing their logical reasoning and critical thinking skills under the guidance of experienced mentors.
eligibility: High school students with strong mathematical ability and interest in exploring advanced topics beyond the school curriculum.
tips: Demonstrate creativity and problem-solving skills in your application.
Engage actively in collaborative learning and mathematical discussions.
Be prepared to tackle challenging problems and think independently.
whatIsLookedFor: Mathematical talent, curiosity, creativity, collaborative spirit, and motivation for intensive study.

title: Euler Circle
details: Euler Circle is a mathematics institute offering advanced college-level mathematics classes for high school students who have exhausted their school curriculum. The program emphasizes problem-solving, proof-writing, and independent research, with opportunities to explore unsolved problems and write expository papers. Classes cover topics such as mathematical thinking, transition to proofs, fundamentals of higher mathematics, and infinite series.
eligibility: High school students with strong mathematical ability and interest in advanced mathematics topics beyond the standard curriculum.
tips: Demonstrate readiness for college-level mathematics in your application.
Be prepared to solve challenging problem sets and engage in proof-writing.
Show motivation for independent research and willingness to tackle unsolved problems.
whatIsLookedFor: Mathematical talent, problem-solving skills, initiative, curiosity, and commitment to rigorous study.

title: Epsilon India Gifted Math Camp
details: Epsilon India is an intensive summer camp for mathematically gifted students aged 9–13. The program provides a challenging curriculum exposing students to substantial mathematical ideas, fostering critical thinking, problem-solving, and mathematical maturity. The camp includes interaction with professional mathematicians, collaborative problem-solving, and a parent program to support nurturing mathematically gifted children.
eligibility: Students aged 9–13 with demonstrated mathematical ability, maturity, and passion for learning mathematics. Selection involves pre-test, teacher recommendations, and parent questionnaire.
tips: Demonstrate passion and interest in mathematics beyond the school curriculum.
Engage with challenging mathematical problems and show curiosity.
Highlight previous achievements or experiences in mathematics in the application.
whatIsLookedFor: Mathematical maturity, creativity, problem-solving skills, curiosity, and enthusiasm for deep learning.

title: BPHO Computational Challenge
details: The BPHO Computational Challenge is a national-level competition in the UK designed to test students’ problem-solving and programming skills within the context of physics. Participants solve computational physics problems using programming and mathematical modeling, developing both theoretical understanding and practical coding ability.
eligibility: High school students in the UK or affiliated schools, typically aged 14–18.
tips: Practice computational problem-solving and physics simulations.
Develop skills in programming languages like Python or MATLAB.
Focus on clear documentation and explanation of code and results.
whatIsLookedFor: Analytical thinking, problem-solving skills, physics understanding, coding ability, and clarity in presentation of results.

title: Episteme 2025
details: Episteme 2025, an initiative by Pravaha in collaboration with IIIT-Hyderabad, is designed to spark curiosity and deepen knowledge across sustainability, climate change, advanced STEM, and innovation. The program combines interactive lectures, hands-on workshops, design challenges, field excursions, and entrepreneurship activities to create a rich, experiential learning environment for young students.
eligibility: Students aged 11–14 (grades 6–9), demonstrating curiosity, creativity, and interest in STEM, sustainability, and innovation.
tips: Highlight interest in STEM, sustainability, and entrepreneurship in your application.
Demonstrate curiosity, creativity, and teamwork abilities.
Be prepared to engage in hands-on projects, field visits, and collaborative challenges.
whatIsLookedFor: Curiosity, creativity, critical thinking, teamwork, problem-solving, and enthusiasm for interdisciplinary learning.

title: IRIS National Science Fair (IRIS)
details: The Initiative for Research and Innovation in STEM (IRIS) is India's most prestigious national-level science fair for school students. It provides a platform for young innovators to present original STEM research and innovations. IRIS is the official pathway for Indian students to qualify for the Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF), the world's largest pre-college research competition.
eligibility: Open to Indian students in Grades 5–12. Projects must demonstrate originality, scientific thought, and potential impact. Both individual and team projects are allowed.
tips: Submit a clear and original abstract with strong scientific reasoning.
Choose a problem with societal or environmental relevance.
Use a proper research methodology and highlight innovation.
Prepare for both written and oral presentations.
Communicate your project in simple yet impactful language.
whatIsLookedFor: Judges value originality, scientific depth, problem-solving ability, and innovation. Strong emphasis is placed on real-world applications, clarity of communication, and the potential societal impact of the research.

title: International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) Competition
details: The International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) Competition is the world’s largest synthetic biology competition, where high school and university teams design, build, and test innovative biological systems. Participants work collaboratively on real-world challenges in health, environment, energy, and more, using genetic engineering and synthetic biology. The competition culminates in the annual iGEM Grand Jamboree, where teams present their projects to an international community of scientists, entrepreneurs, and innovators.
eligibility: Open to high school and undergraduate students worldwide. Teams must register through their schools or organizations and work on a synthetic biology project over several months. Both new and experienced teams are welcome.
tips: Assemble a diverse team with skills in biology, engineering, computer science, and design.
School will register on your behlaf and make teams for the students.
Choose a project that addresses a real-world problem with innovative synthetic biology solutions.
Document your project thoroughly on your iGEM wiki for evaluation.
Engage with the community through outreach and collaboration with other teams.
Prepare for clear and impactful presentations at the iGEM Grand Jamboree.
whatIsLookedFor: iGEM values creativity, interdisciplinary teamwork, scientific rigor, and real-world impact. Judges look for innovation, strong experimental design, thorough documentation, and community engagement.

title: Horizon Academic Essay Prize
details: The Horizon Academic Essay Prize is a global competition that recognizes exceptional academic writing by high school students. Participants submit essays that demonstrate critical thinking, originality, and academic rigor across a range of disciplines. The competition is designed to encourage intellectual curiosity, research-based argumentation, and clarity of communication in young scholars.
eligibility: Open to high school students worldwide (Grades 9–12 or equivalent). Students may submit essays individually on a wide range of academic topics. Originality and clarity of argument are key criteria.
tips: Choose a research question or argument that reflects both originality and depth.
Ensure your essay has a strong thesis statement and logical structure.
Use credible academic sources and proper citations.
Demonstrate critical thinking and clear reasoning throughout your essay.
Revise multiple times for clarity, style, and grammar before submission.
whatIsLookedFor: Judges value originality of thought, depth of research, strong academic writing, and the ability to construct a clear, compelling argument. Clarity, precision, and adherence to academic standards are critical.

title: International Young Physicists’ Tournament (IYPT)
details: The International Young Physicists’ Tournament (IYPT), often called the 'Physics World Cup,' is a prestigious global competition where high school students work in teams to solve open-ended physics problems. Teams prepare research-based solutions over several months and present them in a debate-style format known as 'Physics Fights,' where they defend, oppose, and review solutions in front of an international jury. The tournament emphasizes collaboration, scientific creativity, critical thinking, and communication skills.
eligibility: Open to high school students worldwide (Grades 9–12 or equivalent). Students compete in teams (usually 5 members) selected through national or regional tournaments. Teams must prepare solutions to 17 published physics problems prior to the international event.
tips: Start early by carefully analyzing the 17 IYPT problems released each year.
Combine theory, experiment, and creativity to propose well-rounded solutions.
Practice debate-style presentations to effectively defend and critique physics solutions.
Work collaboratively within your team to divide tasks and refine research quality.
Engage in mock 'Physics Fights' to prepare for the tournament format.
whatIsLookedFor: IYPT values scientific rigor, originality, teamwork, and communication. Judges look for depth of research, experimental evidence, and the ability to present and defend solutions clearly in a debate setting.

title: Harvard Student Research Institute (SRI)
details: The Student Research Institute (SRI) is a virtual summer research program by the Harvard Undergraduate OpenBio Laboratory that aims to democratize access to scientific research for high school students around the world. Participants are paired with PhD mentors to conduct original projects or literature reviews, attend weekly workshops, present their work, and may have their results published in an undergraduate journal. The program is free of cost to admitted students.
eligibility: Open to high school students (grades 9–12) globally. No prior research experience required. Students must be committed to research and scientific inquiry.
tips: Emphasize your curiosity in biology or related fields and show how you've independently explored scientific topics.
Use examples of self-motivated learning, participation in science clubs or projects, and clear scientific questions you might like to explore.
Write strong, thoughtful essays showing your motivations, not just your achievements.
whatIsLookedFor: SRI looks for students with intellectual curiosity, perseverance, self-motivation, and an interest in contributing to scientific research. Strong communication, openness to mentorship, and consistency in work are valued. While past research experience is helpful, it is not required.

title: The Columbia Medicine and Research Summer Program
details: The Medicine and Research Summer Program is hosted by Columbia University Vagelos College of Physicians and Surgeons (VP&S) Global Health Organization in collaboration with the International Young Researchers’ Conference (IYRC). It provides high school students with the opportunity to explore medical research, gain exposure to global health issues, and develop foundational laboratory and clinical research skills. The program combines lectures by Columbia faculty, hands-on workshops, and mentorship from researchers and medical professionals.
eligibility: Open to motivated high school students entering grade 11 with a strong interest in medicine, biology, or related sciences.
tips: Highlight previous biology or chemistry experience in your application.
Show genuine curiosity about medicine and research.
Be clear about your motivation to learn from Columbia faculty.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with strong academic performance, initiative, and genuine interest in pursuing medical or research careers.

title: World Robot Olympiad (WRO)
details: The World Robot Olympiad (WRO) is a global robotics competition that challenges students to design, build, and program robots to solve real-world problems. Each year, WRO announces new themes and challenges, encouraging innovation, teamwork, and creative problem-solving. Students compete in categories such as RoboMission, RoboSports, Future Innovators, and Future Engineers, applying STEM knowledge, coding, and engineering design in an exciting international setting.
eligibility: Open to students worldwide aged 8–19, divided into Elementary, Junior, Senior, and University categories. Teams typically consist of 2–3 students and a coach. Participants must first qualify through regional and national competitions to reach the WRO International Finals.
tips: Study the annual WRO challenge rules carefully and design your robot accordingly.
Develop strong coding and engineering skills to handle both expected and unexpected challenges.
Collaborate effectively within your team to divide tasks (design, coding, testing).
Participate in local robotics clubs or workshops to gain practice ahead of competitions.
Focus on innovation and creativity in both design and problem-solving approaches.
whatIsLookedFor: WRO values innovation, teamwork, problem-solving, and practical application of STEM concepts. Judges look for well-engineered robots, creative solutions, and effective teamwork in handling competition challenges.

title: World Scholar’s Cup (WSC)
details: The World Scholar’s Cup (WSC) is an international team academic competition that brings together students from around the world to engage in collaborative learning and debate. Covering six subjects under an annual theme, participants take part in four events: Team Debate, Scholar’s Challenge (quiz), Collaborative Writing, and the Scholar’s Bowl. WSC emphasizes curiosity, interdisciplinary thinking, teamwork, and fun while creating a global community of scholars.
eligibility: Open to students aged 10–18 worldwide. Teams of three students compete in multiple subject areas and events. No prior experience in debate or writing is required; the competition encourages both beginners and experienced students.
tips: Form a balanced team with diverse strengths in debate, writing, and knowledge quizzes.
Study the annual theme and six subjects thoroughly using the official WSC curriculum.
Practice debating in a team setting to build confidence and collaborative strategy.
Work on writing essays under time pressure to prepare for the Collaborative Writing event.
Enjoy the community aspect—WSC values enthusiasm, curiosity, and global friendships.
whatIsLookedFor: WSC values teamwork, critical thinking, curiosity, and creativity. Judges and facilitators look for students who can engage deeply with ideas, express themselves clearly, and collaborate effectively in diverse formats.

title: Diamond Challenge for High School Entrepreneurs
details: The Diamond Challenge is a global entrepreneurship competition for high school students, designed to inspire innovation, creativity, and leadership. Participants work individually or in teams to develop business ideas, create prototypes, and pitch their concepts to a panel of expert judges. The program provides mentorship, workshops, and feedback to help students transform ideas into actionable solutions, fostering entrepreneurial thinking and problem-solving skills.
eligibility: Open to students worldwide currently in high school (Grades 9–12 or equivalent) aged 14-18. Participants can compete individually or in teams. Students should have a passion for entrepreneurship, problem-solving, and innovation.
tips: Focus on originality and feasibility of your business idea or social venture.
Clearly articulate the problem, solution, market, and impact in your submission.
Demonstrate creativity, research, and critical thinking in your pitch and materials.
Seek mentorship and feedback early to refine your project before submission.
Highlight teamwork, leadership, and your role in developing the project.
whatIsLookedFor: The Diamond Challenge values creativity, innovation, entrepreneurial mindset, feasibility, and impact. Judges look for students who demonstrate initiative, problem-solving, and the ability to translate ideas into actionable solutions.

title: Conrad Challenge
details: The Conrad Challenge is a global, multi-phase innovation and entrepreneurship competition for high school students. Participants develop solutions to real-world problems in STEM, entrepreneurship, and social impact, working individually or in teams. The program emphasizes creativity, collaboration, and critical thinking, with mentorship from experts and opportunities to present solutions to judges, industry leaders, and NASA and Conrad Foundation advisors.
eligibility: Open to high school students worldwide (Grades 9–12 or equivalent) aged 13-18. Participants can compete individually or in teams. Students should have a strong interest in innovation, problem-solving, and entrepreneurship.
tips: Focus on originality, feasibility, and impact of your project.
Demonstrate a clear understanding of the problem and a creative solution approach.
Highlight teamwork, leadership, and your role in developing the project.
Leverage mentorship and resources provided by the Conrad Challenge to refine your idea.
Prepare a strong presentation or pitch with clear communication of your solution and its real-world applications.
whatIsLookedFor: The Conrad Challenge seeks students who are innovative, collaborative, and solutions-oriented. Judges value creativity, critical thinking, problem-solving skills, and the potential impact of the proposed solution.

title: International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF)
details: ISEF is the world’s largest international pre-college science competition, bringing together high school students from around the globe to showcase original research projects in all STEM fields. Participants present their work to expert judges, compete for scholarships, awards, and recognition, and engage with a community of like-minded young scientists. The program emphasizes scientific rigor, creativity, and innovation, providing students with mentorship, networking, and opportunities to attend lectures by world-renowned scientists.
eligibility: Open to high school students worldwide (Grades 9–12 or equivalent) who have completed original research projects in STEM fields. Students must qualify through affiliated local, regional, or national fairs to participate in ISEF.
tips: Ensure your research project is original, well-documented, and follows scientific methodology.
Focus on clarity in your research presentation and report.
Demonstrate creativity, analytical skills, and depth of understanding in your field.
Obtain strong recommendation letters from mentors or teachers familiar with your research.
Prepare to discuss your project in detail with judges and answer questions confidently.
whatIsLookedFor: ISEF values originality, scientific rigor, problem-solving ability, creativity, and effective communication. Judges seek students capable of conducting independent research and presenting it clearly to an expert audience.

title: Breakthrough Junior Challenge
details: The Breakthrough Junior Challenge is an annual global competition for students to create a short video (3 minutes or less) that explains a concept in physics, mathematics, or life sciences in a creative and engaging way. Participants showcase their understanding, communication skills, and creativity, with the opportunity to win scholarships, technology prizes, and the chance to have their work featured worldwide.
eligibility: Open to high school students worldwide (Grades 9–12 or equivalent). Students may submit individually or in teams, and submissions must be original and created by the student(s).
tips: Clearly explain the scientific or mathematical concept in a simple and engaging way.
Use creative storytelling, visuals, and examples to make your video memorable.
Ensure your submission is accurate, scientifically rigorous, and original.
Keep the video concise and within the 3-minute limit.
Highlight your passion for STEM and your ability to communicate complex ideas effectively.
whatIsLookedFor: The competition values clarity of explanation, creativity, originality, and the ability to engage an audience. Judges look for students who can make complex scientific ideas accessible, visually compelling, and memorable.

title: INESPO Olympiade
details: The INESPO Olympiade is an international online competition for high school students that challenges participants in subjects including mathematics, science, and computer science. The competition emphasizes problem-solving, analytical thinking, and the application of knowledge in creative and rigorous ways. Students compete individually or in teams and gain exposure to international academic standards and collaborative problem-solving environments.
eligibility: Open to high school students worldwide (Grades 9–12 or equivalent). Participants may compete individually or in teams, and must demonstrate strong interest and aptitude in STEM subjects.
tips: Prepare thoroughly in mathematics, science, and related subjects relevant to the competition rounds.
Practice problem-solving and analytical reasoning skills under timed conditions.
Collaborate effectively if participating as part of a team and divide tasks strategically.
Review past competition questions if available to understand the format and level of difficulty.
Ensure clear, accurate, and logical presentation of solutions in written submissions or online assessments.
whatIsLookedFor: Students with strong analytical and problem-solving skills, creativity in approaching STEM challenges, and the ability to work independently or in a team. Judges value precision, logical reasoning, and innovative thinking in solutions.
